name: BCITWayFinding
description: Prototype navigation app for the BCIT Burnaby campus. Get directions to buildings from current location.

Context.title: Context
Context.text: New students and faculty were having difficulty navigating the BCIT campus. The only resource available to them was a downloadable PDF map available on the BCIT website.
Context.text2: Google maps does not work for foot paths on campus, so students and faculty would have to go back and forth between google maps and the PDF map.

Scope.title: Scope
Scope.text: This project was developed as a proof of concept wayfinding application for the BCIT Burnaby campus. My team consisted of myself and two other students, and we were given 4 x 1 week sprints for development.
Scope.text2: The main focus of the project was developing a way to get accurate foot path data from the campus, and creating a frontend which would use this data to show the shortest path between any two given points.

Objective.title: Objective
Objective.text: The goal of this project was to create a MVP wayfinding mobile application for the BCIT Burnaby campus. The application would be able to geolocate the user on the campus, and provide them with directions to their destination.

Implementation.title: Implementation
Implementation.text: Since we were only developing a prototype we decided to focus solely on the wayfinding aspect of the app. This allowed us to focus on the core functionality and not get bogged down by the additional features that would be required for a full-fledged app.
Implementation.text2: We ruled out the need to connect the app to a database. Instead, we created a JSON file with the data we needed and used the Google Maps API to display the data on the map.

one.text: The biggest challenge we faced was the lack of data for footpaths on campus. To generate this data we created a JSON to represent the intersections and corners of footpaths on campus.

two.text: We then developed a python script which would interpolate the nodes between the corners and intersections to create a more accurate representation of the footpaths on campus.

points.title: Pain Points
points: Always late because he gets lost around campus
Has diffuculty finding restrooms
Can't climb stairs because of his knee injury

points.title: Goals
points: Easily find his way around campus
Find restrooms easily
Find wheelchair accessible routes

points.title: Needs
points: Search for directions to a specific building
Request wheelchair accessible routes
Find restrooms on campus

FinalDesign.title: final-design
FinalDesign.text: The UI/UX of the app was designed to closely mimic that of Google Maps in order to minimize the learning curve for users. Familiar navigation icons and layouts were employed to make the app easy to understand and use for those already familiar with Google Maps.
FinalDesign.text2: The map view, search bar, and menu options were all modeled after the well-known Google Maps interface to ensure a seamless transition for users.
features: Autocomplete search bar for buildings and amenities
FinalDesign.nextStep: More accurate footpath data is required to improve the functionality of the app. This data could be crowd sourced by students and staff and would include routes that go through buildings and other areas that are not currently included in the app.
FinalDesign.nextStep2: An admin control panel would be required to allow for updating the map, and sending out alerts to all users. This would allow for the app to be used for emergency situations such as fire alarms and lockdowns.

name: SotBy
description: Scheduling and Resource management application developed for the BCIT Automotive Department.

Context.title: Context
Context.text: The faculty of BCIT's Automotive Department were using a shared google file to manage vacations, resources and schedules, which led to a lot of confusion and inefficiency.
Context.text2: Only one person could edit the file at a time, and there was no way to track changes. Due to the lack of error control, if an error was made in the file it would be difficult to find and fix.

Scope.title: Scope
Scope.text: This project was going to eventually replace the old system, and would be used by the faculty to manage their schedules and resources.
Scope.text2: I was apart of the second team to work on this project. The first team had developed a semi-functional backend which had most of the functionality required for the project. My team was given a 4 week sprint to develop a userfriendly frontend for the application.

Objective.title: Objective
Objective.text: My teams objective was to develop a user friendly frontend for the application, as well as implementing a secure login system for various account types.
Objective.text2: Admin account types would be able to edit the schedule, resources and vacations of all users. Faculty account types would be able to edit their own schedule, resources and vacations.

Implementation.title: Implementation
Implementation.text: The team before us had developed a backend for the application using a PERN stack. We used this backend to develop the frontend for the application using React and Material UI.
Implementation.text2: We also implemented a secure login system using JSON Web Tokens and bcrypt. The login system was able to differentiate between admin and faculty account types, and would only allow admin account types to edit the schedule, resources and vacations of all users.

one.text: The main challenge we faced was learning how to use the backend that was developed by the previous team. We had to learn how to use the API endpoints that were developed, and how to use the database.

points.title: Pain Points
points: Wastes time waiting for access to the google sheets
Stresses about having to book resources
Took a long time to learn how to use the google sheets

points.title: Goals
points: Become more efficient
Use faculty resources more effectively
Spend less time booking resources

points.title: Needs
points: A secure login system to request time off
View the schedule of all faculty members
Easily request resources for classes

FinalDesign.title: UI/UX
FinalDesign.text: We decided to make each column in the calendar represent a week, this would allow the user to see the schedule for the entire month at a glance. We also decided to make the calendar view the landing page, so that the user would be able to see the schedule for the current month without having to log in.
FinalDesign.text2: Once logged in users are able to interact with the calendar in order to edit their schedule, request resources and request time off.
features: Drag and drop to edit schedule
FinalDesign.nextStep: The next major step for this project would be to host the application on a server. This would allow the application to be used by all faculty members at BCIT.
FinalDesign.nextStep2: Additional testing and optomization would also be required to ensure that the application is stable and secure.
